title: Boryeong Mud Festival at Daecheon Beach in Boryeong, South Korea
text:
Boryeong Mud Festival at Daecheon Beach in Boryeong, South Korea Last updated 14:10, July 27 2015 KIM HONG-JI/Reuters KIM HONG-JI/Reuters KIM HONG-JI/Reuters KIM HONG-JI/Reuters KIM HONG-JI/Reuters Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images 
Millions of tourists attend the Boryeong Mud Festival at Daecheon Beach in South Korea. 
The annual festival draws around 2 to 3 million visitors. 
Tourists play in a mud pool during the Boryeong Mud Festival. 
A tourists takes a selfie in the crowd. 
A festival-goer poses for photographs. 
The mud, which is believed to have benefical effects on the skin due to its mineral content. 
Festival-goers enjoy the mud during the annual Boryeong Mud Festival. 
The mud is sourced from mud flats near Boryeong. 
...and transported to the beach by truck. 
Festival-goers wrestle in the mud. 
The 18th annual mud festival features mud wrestling and mud sliding. 
The festival runs from July 19-28, but it is most famous for its final weekend. 
Getting the full mud treatment. 
Leaping into the mud bath. 
The massive celebration of all things muddy is based in the South Chungcheong Province, famous for its beautiful beaches and skin-cleansing sludge, and draws more foreigners to Korea than any other event in the country. 
Festival-goers pose for photos, covered in mud. 
Things can get a little chaotic. 
And very crowded... 
It's all just about good, clean fun. 
There's a lot of mud wrestling. 
During the festival there are also mud pools, mud slides and mud skiing competitions. 
Protecting your eyes in important. 
Festival-goers enjoy the mud during the annual Boryeong Mud Festival at Daecheon Beach. 
Festival-goers wrestle in the mud. 
Festival-goers enjoy the mud during the annual Boryeong Mud Festival. 1 of 25 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
Every year, this little town 190 km southwest of Seoul, South Korea, becomes a tourist hot spot. 
Attracting about 2 to 3 million domestic and international visitors, the Boryeong Mud Festival at Daecheon beach is an annual event that aims to encourage the use of mud for cosmetic skincare and promote tourism in the region. 
The 18th annual mud festival features mud wrestling and mud sliding. Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images 
Festival-goers enjoy the mud during the annual Boryeong Mud Festival 
The mud, which is believed to have beneficial effects on the skin due to its mineral content, is sourced from mud flats near Boryeong and transported to the beach by truck.
